item.title: The Best Dolls For Girls' Frontline 2's Steam Release
item.description:
Summary

  • Girls' Frontline 2: Exilium has finally been released worldwide on Steam.
  • Selecting the right T-Dolls is crucial for building a successful team.
  • Team synergy is important, T-Dolls that use the same damage type work together effectively.

Girls’ Frontline 2: Exilium has finally been released to players worldwide on Steam, and with it currently sitting at a Very Positive review score, it's easy to see the global launch is going very well for GFL2 . Naturally, the release has brought many new and long-time fans in to play the long-awaited sequel that has been exclusive to the CN region for the past year. Its updated graphics and stunning new artwork are a big upgrade from the first game, and it seems to be bringing more appeal from a wider audience.

With a whole new story, gameplay mechanics, resources to manage, and much more, GFL2 can seem like a lot to learn for new players just starting out. Not to mention its diverse lineup of new and returning T-Dolls to choose from when building a team, each having unique pros and cons. Players may be tempted to pick team members based on character appearance, but choosing the right T-Doll lineup is crucial for ensuring success across its various missions, challenges, and boss battles.

Some T-Dolls are acquired through premium gacha (Standard or Targeted Procurement Tickets) . While these can be purchased in the store, it is not required as many rewards are given simply through gameplay.

1 Tololo

Good Damage-Dealer

Tololo is an elite doll in GFL2 who is another solid option as a mid-range damage dealer against individual targets. Her abilities deal in both hydro damage and physical damage in the AR class of weapons, where she comes equipped with the Model Alpha AR.

She has a varied range of abilities that use two types of damage respectively; hydro or physical, allowing her more versatility in combat depending on the enemy. Quite possibly the best part about this doll is her passive ability, maxing out her Confectance Index at the start of battle. If maintained at the end of her turn, it grants her another action, essentially allowing her two actions in a single turn.

Although Tololo is a strong damage-dealer with ARs, the downside is that her passive depends on having another Hydro teammate to be the most effective. That being said, having that Extra Action passive ability is a game-changer, even if it's only for a single turn. Together with her incredibly high-damage output, especially when using her ultimate, this doll is another great AR option for ripping through individual targets.

Tololo is currently obtainable through Targeted Procurement Access located in the Recruitment menu section.

2 Daiyan

Best Doll For Damage-Dealing & Utility

Daiyan is an elite doll who was brought in during the Amidst Wings of Gray event, currently being one of the best options as both a damage dealer and utility doll for the team. She deals in physical damage exclusively, having no abilities that deal elemental damage. Using the AR class of weapons, she comes wielding the Type 95 by default.

This T-Doll is notable for her high mobility, as well as her ability to dispel buffs from enemies, allowing her to remove one per turn from whatever enemy she attacks. This is incredibly useful in combat with elites or bosses who can have buffs that are unique and much stronger than the average enemy. This doll is unique in that she only deals in physical damage, meaning she has no element-related abilities like most other dolls. Though this isn’t usually ideal, her ability to destabilize enemies allows her to weaken them to a point where she can deal massive damage if used properly.

As mentioned, Daiyan lacks the capability of dealing elemental damage and although her ability to destabilize enemies can make up for that, elemental damage is much more ideal as it can work synergistically with other dolls using the same damage type. Regardless, Daiyan is still one of the best options, able to output a solid amount of damage, as well as benefit the entire team with her ability to weaken enemies by lowering their stability.

Daiyan is currently not obtainable since her event has ended, but she will most likely be re-added at a later date.

Alternative: Consider using Tololo as an AR Damage Dealer in the meantime.

3 Makiatto

Best SR Doll For Damage-Dealing

Makiatto is an elite doll introduced in GFL2 's Rhapsody Quartet event and is easily the best option as a long-range attacker with high damage output. Like some of the most iconic anime characters ever, she deals in freeze damage and uses the SR category of weapons, coming equipped with the W2000 SR by default.

Her "Absolute Mental Defense" ultimate activates support attacks from allies, allowing them to counter incoming enemy blows. The ability’s key part is that it applies a self-shield, activating her alert effect and making her intercept any incoming attacks against teammates who are in her range. This ability is made even more powerful by the fact that the interception happens before the enemy’s incoming attack, allowing her to possibly eliminate them before they can deal damage to the target.

Makiatto doesn’t really have any downsides to note, as she is currently the best-in-class option for an SR doll. Able to output high amounts of damage at long-range, while also providing some defensive support for her team in the process.

Makiatto is currently not obtainable since her event has ended, but she will most likely be re-added at a later date.

Alternative: Consider using Nemesis as an SR Damage Dealer in the meantime.

4 Qiongjiu

Best AR Doll For Damage-Dealing

Qiongjiu is an elite doll who is currently rated as one of the highest damage-dealing dolls in GFL2 , making her pretty much the go-to AR doll for offense, outperforming almost anything in her way. She deals in burn damage and uses AR weapons, coming stock with the QBZ 191 AR. Qiongjiu is one of those characters that might make new Girls' Frontline 2 players consider re-rolling.

Qiongjiu’s Ultimate is a self-buff ability that focuses entirely on maximizing her damage output. It applies 3 stacks of Action Support II, +30% Action Support, and an additional Action Support, making her total damage multiplier go up to 450% per cast when at maximum Confectance Index. Adding to this, her ultimate has no cooldown, and the Action Support II buff doesn’t dispel, so it will continue to stack with repeated uses.

Again, Qiongjiu pretty much has no notable downsides at the moment in GFL2 . Although she doesn’t provide any team utility or support in her abilities directly, her incredibly high damage output is support enough in all situations, especially when it comes to Elite battles and boss fight challenges.

Qiongjiu is currently obtainable through Targeted Procurement Access located in the Recruitment menu section.

5 Suomi

Best Doll For Support & Utility

Suomi is an elite doll who is currently one of the best offered in this tactical RPG and can be effective on nearly all fronts, especially as a supporter for the rest of the team. She deals in freeze damage and uses the Suomi KP-31 SMG by default. Aside from support, Suomi can also deal a considerably high amount of damage on her own, making her a good all-rounder to have in a team.

Suomi’s ultimate ability, "Snowfield's Radiance", applies a shield to all allies no matter where they are located on the map, allowing them to tank most regular attacks. This is especially effective if Suomi is kept safe away from the center of battle so she can constantly reuse her ultimate to continue shielding. The ability also recovers her stability, removes any debuffs, as well as cleanses the taunt debuff from all the other team members.

The only downsides to Suomi right now are her smaller movement range and her abilities being mostly focused on defense rather than offense, but the trade-off is well worth it considering how powerful she can be in almost any team.

Suomi is currently obtainable through Targeted Procurement Access located in the Recruitment menu section.

item.title: Mech Arena Promo Codes (February 2025)
item.description:
Mech Arena is a dynamic multiplayer shooter for mobile devices in which you can experience an unforgettable experience of controlling a mech. Having chosen a large robot and equipped it with parts and weapons, you can go to one of the game modes to test your skills and earn currency to buy something more powerful. Victories bring tons of valuable currency rewards and even cases, but if you want to get something for free, use Mech Arena promo codes.

Using codes, you can get in-game currency, components for your mechs, or other stuff. However, codes have a limited expiration date, so you should use them as soon as possible.

Updated February 15, 2025, by Artur Novichenko: Currently, only 2 codes are active, but that shouldn't stop you from bookmarking this guide. We add new freebies as soon as they appear online, so be sure to check back and share this guide with your friends.

All Mech Arena Codes

Working Mech Arena Codes

  • MIDGAMEGIFT - Enter this code to get the 200 A-coins and Credits.
  • MIDGAMER - Enter this code to get the Prodigy Crate.

Expired Mech Arena Codes

  • HOLIDAYMECH - Enter this code to get the 300 A-coins, 100k Credits, an Amateur Crate, and the Legendary skin Slay Ride for Killshot.
  • SPOOKYSHOT - Enter this code to get the Epic Skins.
  • mech3years - Enter this code to get the Golden Age Epic Skin.
  • FIREPOWER - Enter this code to get the rare weapon Rocket Mortar 10.
  • CHAMPION - Enter this code to get the Skin.

While you can get all the best parts and weapons for your mechs by just playing the game, sometimes there's nothing better than a little freebie. Of course, you will not get super powerful items using the codes, but you can get a decent weapon or some money to buy new items quite early on. After all, replenishing your hangar with new components is one of every player's main goals, allowing you to diversify the gameplay significantly. However, reward codes have a limited expiration date, so hurry up and get all of them.

How to Redeem Mech Arena Codes

Unlike in many mobile games, the ability to redeem codes in Mech Arena is available from the first seconds of the gameplay. To do this, you need to copy the active code and follow these steps:

  • Launch Mech Arena .
  • Once in the main menu, click on the envelope icon at the top of the screen to go to the Mail tab.
  • Go to the Promo Code tab.
  • Enter the code in the Enter Promo Code text box.
  • Click Confirm, and you will receive your rewards.

How to Get More Mech Arena Codes

As with most other free mobile games, you can find more Mech Arena promo codes during events and holidays or as a regular promotional reward created to increase popularity. You can find a list of all new codes by checking our guide periodically. However, if you want to keep abreast of all the in-game news, you can follow the official developer pages:

  • Discord
  • Twitter
  • Facebook
  • YouTube

Mech Arena is available on mobile devices.

item.title: Avowed: How To Increase Movement Speed Early
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Get the Arcanist's Boots in Avowed

Avowed features an expansive open world that players must traverse on foot to reach from one area to another. Since you'll be relying on walking, sprinting, and parkour while traveling, it's recommended that you increase your movement speed early on in the game. Players can acquire the Arcanist's Boots, a unique set of clothing that can increase the base movement speed, making traveling a little bit speedier. Here's how to get it.

How to Get the Arcanist's Boots in Avowed

Players can find the Lighthouse west of Claviger's Landing in the Dawnshore area of Avowed . After fast traveling to the beacon in Claviger's Landing, keep heading forward, past the houses until you see a vaultable ledge on the left with some boxes stacked along the wall. Vault over the wall and head past the farmstead to spot the towering Lighthouse along the shoreline.

After approaching the structure, you'll spot a ladder leading up to the exterior of the Lighthouse. You must start climbing the lighthouse as the Arcanist's Boots are at the top.

Reaching the Top of the Lighthouse & Getting Arcanist's Boots

Climbing the Lighthouse to reach the Arcanist's Boots is a little tricky in Avowed . So, here's a step-by-step guide on how to climb it and all the collectibles you'll find along the way.

Players may switch to third-person mode as it can make the climb a little bit easier.

  1. After you climb up the ladder, you'll need to carefully move across the beam and parkour over the wooden platform.
  2. Once you climb another wooden platform, turn around and walk up the planks leading to an elevated platform.
  3. You'll spot a platform above you that you need to jump up and grab to climb.
  4. At the top, you'll encounter a higher platform that you cannot climb directly. First, jump onto the roof of the lower platform on the left and then climb to the higher one.
  5. There's a crack in the wall with a tree growing out of it. Enter the section and grab the Golden Plaque of Promises Totem Fragment.
  6. Now resume scaling the Lighthouse by walking two sets of beams outside the broken wall to come across a skeleton. Loot it to acquire some valuable items, including Captain Henqua's Spoils Treasure Map in Avowed .
  7. Now you'll need to jump across a series of gaps until you reach a ladder that will lead you to the top of the Lighthouse. Here, you'll find a chest that will reward you with the Arcanist's Boots in Avowed .

The Arcanist's Boots has a passive skill called "Lesser Quickness," which will increase players' movement speed by 10% . In addition to the movement speed buff, it'll also grant an item bonus to players which will increase health restoration from all sources by 5% . Overall, it's one of the best pieces of unique equipment you can get early on in Avowed .

item.title: Nvidia RTX: Top 29 Games That Utilize Ray Tracing The Best
item.description:
Summary

  • Real-time ray tracing, like Nvidia RTX, guarantees more physically accurate graphics for visually stunning gameplay experiences.
  • Many games, like Marvel's Guardians of the Galaxy and Wolfenstein: Youngblood , benefit from ray tracing to enhance their visuals.
  • RTX technology is advancing to make most games look photorealistic only seen in a handful of titles, like The Witcher 3 and Cyberpunk 2077 .

It was in 2018 when Nvidia revealed its real-time ray tracing technology for games, titled Nvidia RTX. At the time, many people thought it to be the next best thing for video games, while others felt that it was going to be a side thing, like Nvidia Physx. Fast-forward to 2021, it's been over two years since RTX cards hit the market and many new games have opted for the technology. This is why it's interesting to see how many of these games have used it to goodwill.

RTX technology is all about real-time lighting, and its interaction with the environment. This doesn't always mean good visuals, but yes, guarantees more physically accurate graphics. As graphics cards become more and more advanced over time, ray tracing technology will reach new heights that will make most games look downright photorealistic, which is groundbreaking for obvious reasons. Players will have their minds blown once ray tracing technology reaches a level where pretty much every game will have it, but for now, only a handful of titles have managed to integrate this technology with great finesse.

Updated February 15, 2025, by Hamza Haq: Having ray tracing as a toggle in-game is not an achievement in and of itself. It's only when the implementation is so good that players can immediately tell the difference between RTX On and RTX Off that one really starts to appreciate how far rendering technology has come in recent years. Games that use a lot of reflective surfaces are the best showcases of what ray tracing can achieve, whereas games where most of the environment is mostly opaque, like grassy terrain, it's very difficult for ray tracing to show its true value. Two new games that exemplify this have been added to the article to give players even more options to choose from.

29 Dragon's Dogma 2

The Ray Tracing Improves The Visuals Without Too Much Of A Performance Hit

Dragon's Dogma 2 has been put through the wringer for its poor optimization, and most players should do their research to see whether this game has received enough updates to finally run smoothly on PC and consoles before taking the plunge. It's a shame since the combat of this title takes all the strengths from the first game and dials it up to a hundred.

While it's true that Dragon's Dogma 2 may not be a looker compared to other big-budget AAA games, the ray tracing technology at play here does a great job of ensuring that the lighting of the game looks premium, which helps the graphics stand out even more. Players with systems who can support this state-of-the-art technology will get completely immersed in one of the best action games with ray tracing they can get their hands on.

28 Dying Light 2

Ray Tracing Is The Intended Way To Enjoy The Visuals, With Regular Lighting Looking Flat In Comparison

Dying Light is a game that came out of nowhere and surprised players with a fun mix of parkour and zombie action. Fans were glad to see that a sequel was in the works that sported a bigger budget and would strive to build on the first game's strengths. While the story-heavy nature of Dying Light 2 didn't wow many fans, the moment-to-moment gameplay and familiar combat made it a worthwhile game to check out for Dying Light fans.

The bigger budget for this game could be seen in the title's amazing ray-traced visuals, which completely dwarfed the baked lighting and almost made it look like a second thought. Given the first-person viewpoint of this game, anything that enhances the player's immersion is worth sacrificing some FPS for, and the game's great ray tracing makes it a visual spectacle as players deal with harrowing zombies and the like.

27 Ghostwire: Tokyo

The Ray Tracing Has A Major Hit On Performance But Makes Tokyo Look Breathtaking

The fate of Tango Gameworks has sent ripples through the video game industry, with Xbox's decision to shutter this studio being criticized to the moon and back. Reports state that the studio's main project, Ghostwire: Tokyo , failed to meet sales expectations, even if Hi-Fi Rush was a surprise hit that bagged a ton of awards. It's a shame, since Ghostwire: Tokyo has a lot of strengths despite its open-world design being slightly uninspired.

The visuals of this game are undoubtedly its strongest suit, featuring high-quality animations that are a joy to witness in first-person. If players enable this game's ray-tracing mode, they'll be greeted with an impressive visual display. This ensures that the city of Tokyo feels more moody and immersive than ever before as players battle ghosts and uncover the mystery behind the disappearance of this city's residents.

26 Marvel’s Guardians Of The Galaxy

The Diverse Color Palette Looks Even Better With Ray Tracing Enabled

The release of Marvel's Avengers made many fans fear the worst for the Guardians of the Galaxy game, which is perhaps why so many people weren't looking forward to this release. While this story-driven single-player game was released to poor sales, it didn't take long for public perception to turn after more and more people talked about the amazing nature of this game's narrative.

The combat, despite being the title's weak aspect, still has many things that go for it. However, it's the story and characters that end up being the saving grace of a video game that knows how to bamboozle players and let players enjoy an intergalactic narrative for the ages. This, coupled with the game's great ray-tracing , makes it a veritable gaming feast that boasts both style and substance.

25 HITMAN World of Assassination

Ray Tracing Adds Another Dimension To Agent 47’s Assassination Experience

HITMAN World of Assassination is the definitive Hitman experience, combining all of Hitman 1, 2, and 3 in a single package, updated and upgraded to work with the latest RTX technology. Players take on the role of the iconic Agent 47 to carry out target assassinations, using everything from Sniper Rifles to Gas Canisters to poisoned drinks. Planning out the perfect assassination in as short a time frame as possible without being seen is the sign of a true professional.

Agent 47's targets are mostly found in crowded urban spaces, environments filled with reflective surfaces like windows. This is where ray tracing really shines, allowing players to appreciate the extent to which the technology can take games on full display.

24 Avatar: Frontiers Of Pandora

A Gorgeous World That Comes To Life When The Lighting Is Cranked To The Max

It's a shame that Avatar: Frontiers of Pandora didn't live up to its initial hype, feeling more like a reskinned Far Cry game than an original Avatar title. The focus on dated crafting mechanics and the dependence on scanning for efficient exploration took away a lot from Pandora's gorgeous landscapes, which come to life with the use of ray tracing.

The biomes in Pandora are a treat to witness firsthand and one of the strongest aspects of the game. If a huge priority for a player is to witness a wealth of beautiful curated landscapes, then using ray tracing is downright necessary to make Pandora come to life in the best way possible, and to further the joys of James Cameron's Avatar .

23 Alan Wake 2

The Imaginative Art Style Of This Game Benefits From Ray Tracing Turned On

A game absolutely bursting with style and atmosphere, it's easy to see why Alan Wake 2 is one of the best video games of 2023. Remedy was at its very best when it developed this stellar survival horror game that isn't afraid to take risks. People who love Remedy when they're at their most creative will love just how unique and different Alan Wake 2 is.

It's easy to see why fans can't wait for Remedy to churn out another game, especially with Alan Wake 2 essentially creating a shared universe for all Remedy games. With the critical success of Alan Wake 2 leaving many people impressed, fans can only hope that more AAA developers take the same risk that Remedy did in the creation of a unique story-driven adventure that is unlike anything players have experienced before.

22 Returnal

A Mind-Bending Roguelike Game That Looks Pretty Amazing To Boot

Many people are glad to see huge studios like Sony try their hands out on genres that most AAA games don't try to experiment with. Not only is Returnal a pretty excellent roguelike, but the story it tells is a captivating psychological horror drama that will keep players invested from start to end.

Selene is a deceptively complicated character whose backstory is slowly revealed over the course of the game's narrative. Repetition is a common theme prevalent in both the gameplay and narrative of the game, showing just how underrated Housemarque's AAA roguelike game really is.

21 A Plague Tale: Requiem

A Sequel That Ups The Ante In Every Way, Including Its Visuals

A Plague Tale: Innocence is an indie game that came out of nowhere and wowed people with its emotional story and excellent presentation. The idea of playing as two struggling survivors in a stealth-focused indie title during the Black Plague makes for a great time, and the sight of millions of rats hounding them every step of the way will be burned into the player's mind at the end of this experience.

So, it was only a matter of time before this hit title would receive a sequel that is bigger, better, and bolder in every way. A Plague Tale: Requiem is an excellent sequel that wraps up Amicia and Hugo's tale in a bold manner, making for a spectacular story-driven journey that is rife with amazing visuals. The title supports RTX, becoming even more visually appealing if players turn this option on.

20 Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered

A Web-Slinging Marvel In New York City

Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered doesn't really add all that much to the original game in terms of story, content, or even cosmetics. There are a couple of new suits players can unlock, the GOTY version DLCs and slightly better facial animations, but little else. The value proposition for this remaster lies almost entirely in how they have managed to elevate the graphical fidelity from the base game, primarily through the excellent implementation of ray tracing.

For machines that can handle it, there are few things prettier than web-slinging through a hyper-realistic New York City as Spiderman. The easiest way to notice the effects of RTX is to stick to a window on a skyscraper and look at the reflection. It's like looking into a mirror. Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a gorgeous game without RTX, but when it is turned on, it turns into pure eye candy.

19 Crysis Remastered Trilogy

A Trilogy That Was The Peak Of PC Gaming Before, With The Remaster Adding RTX Support

There was a time when the phrase "Can it run Crysis ?" became synonymous with video game meme culture. Crysis truly was a spectacle when it was launched, with CryEngine flexing its muscles as the next great video game engine in the industry. At the time, only the highest-end PCs could even think about running Crysis at its highest setting, with the game looking gorgeous.

In many ways, the game itself wasn't a big deal as much as the engine was, but that didn't mean that the title wasn't fun to play through by any stretch of the imagination. In fact, with the advent of the Crysis Remastered Trilogy , players can experience the magic of the first three games with a fresh coat of paint. Fittingly enough, this collection arrives with ray tracing support, carrying forward the proud legacy of these titles still running rather choppily on regular gaming hardware.

18 Dead Space

A Remake Of A Popular Survival-Horror Game That Justifies Its Presence In Many Ways, Including Upgraded Visuals

Many people argued whether Dead Space really needed a remaster, to begin with. The title looks perfectly fine even now and many people argued that any visual improvements would be superficial, at best. However, the release of this 2023 remake ended up silencing any critics by looking gorgeous while also featuring expanded levels and tweaked combat.

To make things look even better, players could turn on ray tracing to make the cramped halls of the USG Ishimura look even more oppressive and bleak. The graphics of this title alone justify its stature as a worthy remake, even if many people won't be enjoying this revamped lighting when Isaac's head is getting ripped off by a necromorph.

17 The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

The Next-Gen Update Adds Ray Tracing To The Game

The next-gen update for The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt updates the visuals in a way that makes this game look pretty modern. While this update had some rough edges that needed to be ironed out, there's no denying that this visual upgrade is a feast for the eyes. The ray-traced lighting and ambient occlusion genuinely look incredible, and players will be dumbstruck whenever they witness a picturesque sunset in this game. Rescuing Ciri can wait since appreciating this lighting and riding off into the sunset on Roach takes priority.

If anything, The Witcher 3 is a great example of why ray tracing is proving to be such a mind-blowing piece of technology that can elevate any video game to new heights. It's been almost a decade since the game's release, yet it's hard to point out anything dated from a graphical point of view when players turn on ray tracing and have their minds blown by the incredible escalation in quality this game enjoys.

16 Ghostrunner 2

The Futuristic Cyberpunk Environment Shines With RTX On

Ghostrunner 2 takes up the mantle from its predecessor and ups the ante in a big way. Players take first-person control of a futuristic ninja in a cyberpunk setting, wielding a powerful sword. Combat is brutal, but the frequent checkpoints make figuring out the perfect solution to a difficult encounter less frustrating than it has any right to be. The gameplay remains top-notch, the one-hit-one-kill mechanic is as satisfying as ever, and the parkour is just as exquisite as the previous game.

One of the aspects where Ghostrunner 2 really shines is in the visuals. The futuristic setting lends itself extremely well to ray tracing, with the difference between having it on and off being night and day. The environments are beautiful without any RTX, but with it? They are absolutely stunning.

15 Portal

A Free DLC For The Game Lets Players Enjoy This Masterpiece With Ray Tracing

Portal was a groundbreaking puzzle game that proved once again why Valve is considered to be the master of its craft. Players who want an excuse to check out this game once again can do the same with a free DLC for the game that adds ray tracing.

Exploring the test chambers of Aperture with this revamped lighting makes for a great time. The title still holds up to this day, and this visual upgrade makes a new playthrough feel fresh and interesting once again. The fact that a game as clean-looking as Portal can somehow look even better with the smart integration of ray tracing is a great endorsement of this technology.

14 Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales

Documents Miles' First Time Webslinging Without Peter In A Glorious, Beautiful World

Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales serves as a standalone expansion that explores Miles' journey as the new Spider-Man and how he adjusts to these powers. This game serves as the perfect way to fill in the blanks before the advent of Marvel's Spider-Man 2 .

It helps that this game looks gorgeous, with ray tracing enhancing the visuals of this title even more. Players who want to swing through New York in style will be able to do the same with ray-traced lighting cranked up to the max in Spider-Man: Miles Morales .

13 Watch Dogs: Legion

A Unique Take On What A Protagonist Can Be In A Video Game, With RTX Technology Enhancing The Visuals

Watch Dogs: Legion is a game with a pretty innovative take on DedSec recruitment, but the rest of the title is woefully lacking. It's a shame since this game actually took some innovative steps forward, but this came at the cost of the title regressing in several other departments.

Watch Dogs: Legion also features ray tracing which makes the title look pretty astounding indeed. Players who want to mess about in an open-world game with beautiful visuals should look no further than Watch Dogs: Legion .

12 Shadow Of The Tomb Raider

Lara's Final Chapter In The Rebooted Trilogy That Looks Incredible

Shadow of the Tomb Raider is the final title in the rebooted Tomb Raider trilogy, which was a disappointment for many players. The enhancement of underwater segments coupled with ray tracing technology certainly helps the title look brilliant, but that doesn't make up for its unimaginative gameplay.

With the studio behind this game being sold off to Embracer Group, fans don't know what the future of the Tomb Raider series is. Thankfully, Shadow of the Tomb Raider looks great enough with ray-traced lighting and can hold over fans until the next game comes out.

11 Far Cry 6

A Somewhat Disappointing Sequel, But Definitely Shines From A Visual Standpoint

Many people were disappointed with Far Cry 6 upon launch. The game could've been something truly great but was ultimately held back by Ubisoft's cut-and-paste design, rendering it devoid of any creative zeal.

However, the game itself was undeniably very pretty to look at. Switching RTX on turns Far Cry 6 into a beautiful title indeed, with the various reflective surfaces in the game doing a great job of making the title look all the more realistic and engaging.

10 Doom Eternal

The Doom Slayer's Bloody Journey Continues In A Title That Looks Jaw-Droppingly Good

The reboot of Doom was nothing short of an absolute masterpiece. So, it was only a matter of time before a sequel to the same was also released, and this appeared in the form of Doom Eternal .

This title was essentially the first game but bigger, better, and more engaging. It helped that the graphics of this title were spectacular as well and could look even more unreal with the enhancements brought about by ray tracing.

item.title: 8 BioWare Games With The Best Real-Time Combat, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • BioWare has developed stellar games with engaging real-time combat.
  • Combat systems are tactical and engaging, offering unique class abilities.
  • Despite recent struggles, BioWare still shines in creating immersive combat experiences.

BioWare isn't enjoying the greatest time in the industry right now. The lack of compelling original titles has many fans worried about the developer's future, especially since they used to have no problems enticing players with their amazing stories and memorable characters.

Despite these issues, there's no denying that BioWare has developed its fair share of stellar video games that fans can't get enough of. Almost every game developed by this company features real-time combat, with some being more engaging and cathartic than others.

8 Baldur's Gate 2: Shadows Of Amn

The Classic D&D Combat Is A Blast To Play

While the original Baldur's Gate was fun to play in its own right, it wasn't until the release of the sequel that the full potential of the combat system could be achieved. Magic is more important than ever before, and party members are more durable than before.

This means that players are encouraged to take risks with their party members while also employing the skills and abilities required to get through hard-as-nails encounters. The real-time combat is tactical and engaging as players slowly get stronger and try to stop the compelling villain Jon Irenicus from achieving his diabolical plans.

7 Dragon Age: Origins

Excellent Real-Time With Pause Combat That's Tactical And Engaging

Even after the many years that have passed since the release of Dragon Age: Origins , fans still love the game's strategic combat. Players must be careful about the build they're pursuing as they master an array of powerful abilities to take out the myriad of foes in their way.

Warriors should be on the frontlines to serve as tanks. Rogues should use their stealth capabilities and high DPS to quickly kill foes. Finally, mages should stay at a distance and use an array of elemental attacks to make their enemies squeal. If the real-time combat gets hectic, fans can always pause the gameplay and issue individual commands to make things easier for themselves.

6 Jade Empire

Employ Various Martial Arts Stances Against Various Opponents

Jade Empire is one of the most underrated BioWare games, and more people should check it out. This wuxia RPG is unlike anything else out there, and it's a shame that BioWare didn't find this IP promising enough for more sequels.

Combat in this title involves a ton of martial arts stances that must be switched out from time to time to target enemy weaknesses. As players acquire more abilities to overwhelm their opponents, Jade Empire becomes a blast to play through as the protagonist becomes a powerful martial artist who can best their master in combat by the end of the game.

5 Mass Effect 3

The Action-Packed Shootouts Are The Best Of The Commander Shepard Trilogy

While many people weren't huge fans of Mass Effect 3 for its lackluster ending, the gameplay is a different matter altogether. Fans were impressed by how great it felt to rain hellfire on their enemies, with Shepard using a wealth of unique abilities based on their class to make combat even more exhilarating.

Using Biotic powers to propel Shepard's body forward and slam against foes never gets tiring, especially if players have a shotgun to punish enemies at a close range. Along with this, players can command their squadmates to pull off special moves of their own in combat, adding a simple layer of strategy to every combat encounter that players can rely on if things get dire.

4 Dragon Age: Inquisition

Real-Time Combat Where Every Class Feels Unique

After the lackluster release of Dragon Age 2 , fans wanted the sequel to channel Origins ' strengths instead of trying to appeal to mainstream audiences. Thankfully, despite the problems Inquisition faced in development, most fans were elated by what was on display in this title.

Along with an epic story, combat in Inquisition felt better than ever and made every class and specialization fun to use. Activating abilities in the middle of a heated encounter could turn the tide of battle in a flash and make combat look more cinematic than ever before.

3 Anthem

The Game Had Its Issues, But The Combat Is Great

Anthem is one of the biggest EA and BioWare failures of all time, trying to dive into the live service genre only to come out with nothing. It's a shame, since the combat system was engaging enough that the game could have been a success had the other aspects been just as content-rich.

Combat embraces the verticality enabled by the Javelin exosuits, with players flying all over the environment as they dodge enemy attacks and pepper them with damaging hits. While Anthem was a failed experiment that was eventually forgotten, fans were glad to see that remnants of this action-packed combat system were present in another BioWare title.

2 Mass Effect: Andromeda

The Verticality And Fast-Paced Combat Feels Amazing

Fans eagerly anticipating the launch of Mass Effect: Andromeda were left with a bitter taste in their mouths after a botched release full of bugs and other issues. While these were eventually patched, the lack of urgency in the story, coupled with the lackluster writing of each character, turned Andromeda into the worst Mass Effect game by a country mile.

However, players who managed to ignore its faults were pleased by the improvements made to the series' combat. Players could use jetpacks to fly around combat arenas and decimate enemies in style. These dynamic encounters coupled with some impressive abilities make it clear why combat is one area where Andromeda is a massive upgrade over its predecessors.

1 Dragon Age: The Veilguard

Despite Its Issues, Dragon Age Combat Has Never Been Better

People were worried about the release of Dragon Age: The Veilguard , especially with pre-release trailers forsaking the dark edge that made previous Dragon Age games such a blast to play. Unfortunately, the milquetoast writing meant that players struggled to get invested in a story where things just had to stay upbeat no matter what.

Fans were also worried about the action-oriented approach of combat where they couldn't control other party members. However, this is an area where BioWare didn't disappoint. Their modern combat systems have always been action-packed, and the expansive suite of abilities that Rook has access to in The Veilguard turns them into a whirlwind of death at higher levels. Players can zip around the battlefield in high-stakes combat encounters and showing enemies who's boss.
